canonical_explanation.text: India is a land of many festivals. We celebrate festivals like Diwali, Holi, Eid, Christmas, Pongal, and Baisakhi. During festivals, we wear new clothes, eat sweets, and spend time with family and friends. We also celebrate national days like Republic Day and Independence Day. Festivals teach us to share, love, and be happy together.
rules: India has many festivals celebrated by different people.
Diwali is the festival of lights. We light diyas and burst crackers.
Holi is the festival of colours. We play with colours and water.
Eid, Christmas, Pongal, and Baisakhi are also important festivals.
On Republic Day (26 January) and Independence Day (15 August), we celebrate our nation.
Festivals bring family and friends together.

questions.question_text: Which festival is called the 'Festival of Lights'?
questions.explanation_correct: Diwali is called the Festival of Lights. People light diyas, candles, and decorate their homes with lights.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Holi is the festival of colours, Eid is celebrated after Ramadan, and Christmas celebrates the birth of Jesus. Diwali is the Festival of Lights.

questions.question_text: Which festival is called the 'Festival of Colours'?
questions.explanation_correct: Holi is called the Festival of Colours. People play with coloured powder and water during Holi.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diwali is the festival of lights, Christmas celebrates the birth of Jesus, and Pongal is a harvest festival. Holi is the Festival of Colours.

questions.question_text: On which date do we celebrate Republic Day?
questions.explanation_correct: We celebrate Republic Day on 26 January. On this day, there is a big parade in New Delhi.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 15 August is Independence Day, 2 October is Gandhi Jayanti, and 25 December is Christmas. Republic Day is celebrated on 26 January.

questions.question_text: On which date do we celebrate Independence Day?
questions.explanation_correct: We celebrate Independence Day on 15 August. On this day, our national flag is hoisted and we sing patriotic songs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 26 January is Republic Day, 25 December is Christmas, and 1 January is New Year. Independence Day is on 15 August.

questions.question_text: What do we light during Diwali?
questions.explanation_correct: We light diyas and candles during Diwali. Diyas are small oil lamps that make our homes bright and beautiful.
questions.explanation_incorrect: We play with colours during Holi, not Diwali. During Diwali, we light diyas and candles to celebrate the festival of lights.

questions.question_text: What do people play with during Holi?
questions.explanation_correct: During Holi, people play with colours and water. They put coloured powder (gulal) on each other and have fun.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diyas and candles are for Diwali. During Holi, people play with colours (gulal) and water and have a lot of fun together.

questions.question_text: Christmas is the birthday of ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Christmas celebrates the birthday of Jesus Christ. It is celebrated on 25 December every year.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lord Rama's birthday is Rama Navami, Prophet Muhammad's birthday is Eid Milad-un-Nabi, and Guru Nanak's birthday is Guru Nanak Jayanti. Christmas is the birthday of Jesus Christ.

questions.question_text: What do we decorate during Christmas?
questions.explanation_correct: During Christmas, we decorate a Christmas tree with stars, bells, lights, and gifts. It looks very beautiful.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rangoli and kolam are made during Diwali and Pongal. Diyas are for Diwali. During Christmas, we decorate a Christmas tree.

questions.question_text: Pongal is a harvest festival celebrated mainly in ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Pongal is a harvest festival mainly celebrated in Tamil Nadu. People cook sweet rice called Pongal and thank the Sun and farm animals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Punjab celebrates Baisakhi, and Kerala celebrates Onam. Pongal is a harvest festival celebrated mainly in Tamil Nadu.

questions.question_text: Baisakhi is a harvest festival celebrated mainly in ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Baisakhi is a harvest festival mainly celebrated in Punjab. Farmers celebrate the new harvest with dancing and singing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tamil Nadu celebrates Pongal, and West Bengal celebrates Durga Puja. Baisakhi is a harvest festival celebrated mainly in Punjab.

questions.question_text: During festivals, we share sweets and gifts with family and friends.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. During festivals, we share sweets, gifts, and happiness with our family and friends.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. Sharing sweets and gifts with family and friends is an important part of celebrating festivals.

questions.question_text: Republic Day is celebrated on 15 August.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Republic Day is celebrated on 26 January, not 15 August. Independence Day is celebrated on 15 August.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is false. Republic Day is on 26 January. The date 15 August is for Independence Day, not Republic Day.

questions.question_text: Rina is wearing new clothes, eating sweets, and lighting diyas. Which festival is she celebrating?
questions.explanation_correct: Rina is celebrating Diwali. Lighting diyas, wearing new clothes, and eating sweets are all part of Diwali celebrations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: During Holi we play with colours, during Eid there are special prayers, and Baisakhi has bhangra dance. Lighting diyas is a sign of Diwali.

questions.question_text: Children are playing with gulal and pichkaris. Which festival are they celebrating?
questions.explanation_correct: The children are celebrating Holi. Gulal (coloured powder) and pichkaris (water guns) are used to play during Holi.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diwali has diyas, Christmas has trees, and Eid has special prayers. Playing with gulal and pichkaris means they are celebrating Holi.

questions.question_text: Why do we celebrate festivals?

options.text: To be happy together with family and friends

questions.explanation_correct: We celebrate festivals to be happy together with family and friends. Festivals bring people closer and spread joy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Festivals are not about fighting or being alone. We celebrate festivals to be happy together with family and friends and share love.

questions.question_text: What special food is cooked during Eid?
questions.explanation_correct: Sewaiyan (vermicelli) is a special sweet dish cooked during Eid. Families prepare it and share it with neighbours.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pongal rice is for Pongal, Christmas cake is for Christmas. During Eid, people cook sewaiyan (sweet vermicelli) and share it.

questions.question_text: On Republic Day, what do we see in New Delhi?
questions.explanation_correct: On Republic Day, we see a grand parade in New Delhi. Soldiers, school children, and colourful floats are part of the parade.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diya lighting is for Diwali, colour playing is for Holi, and Christmas tree is for Christmas. On Republic Day, there is a grand parade in New Delhi.

questions.question_text: During Diwali, Anu gives sweets to her neighbours. What does this show?
questions.explanation_correct: Anu is sharing happiness with her neighbours. Giving sweets during festivals is a way of spreading joy and love.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Giving sweets to neighbours is not wasting food or being selfish. It shows that Anu is sharing happiness during the festival.

questions.question_text: Which festival is celebrated by tying a rakhi on the brother's wrist?
questions.explanation_correct: During Raksha Bandhan, sisters tie a rakhi on their brother's wrist. It celebrates the bond of love between brothers and sisters.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Holi is for colours, Diwali is for lights, and Eid is after Ramadan. Raksha Bandhan is the festival where sisters tie a rakhi on their brother's wrist.

questions.question_text: Onam is a harvest festival celebrated in ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Onam is a harvest festival celebrated in Kerala. People make beautiful flower carpets called Pookalam and eat a grand feast called Onam Sadya.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Punjab celebrates Baisakhi and Tamil Nadu celebrates Pongal. Onam is the harvest festival celebrated in Kerala.

questions.question_text: Festivals teach us to share and be happy together.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Festivals teach us to share food, gifts, and happiness with everyone. They bring people together.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. Festivals are about sharing, caring, and celebrating together with family and friends.

questions.question_text: Salim's family is praying and then eating sewaiyan together. Which festival are they celebrating?
questions.explanation_correct: Salim's family is celebrating Eid. Special prayers and eating sewaiyan are important parts of Eid celebrations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diwali has diyas, Holi has colours, and Christmas has a Christmas tree. Praying and eating sewaiyan are part of Eid.

questions.question_text: What do people make in front of their houses during Diwali?
questions.explanation_correct: People make rangoli in front of their houses during Diwali. Rangoli is a beautiful pattern made with coloured powder on the floor.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Snowmen are made in cold places, sand castles on beaches. During Diwali, people make beautiful rangoli patterns in front of their homes.

questions.question_text: What do we hoist on Independence Day?
questions.explanation_correct: On Independence Day, we hoist our national flag, the Tiranga. It has three colours: saffron, white, and green, with a blue wheel.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kites, balloons, and banners are not what we specially hoist on Independence Day. We hoist our national flag, the Tiranga.

questions.question_text: Raju and his friends celebrate different festivals. What does this teach us?

options.text: We should only celebrate our own festival
We should respect all festivals and celebrate together

questions.explanation_correct: We should respect all festivals and celebrate together. India has many festivals, and we can enjoy all of them with our friends.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All festivals are important. We should respect every festival and celebrate together. This makes our country beautiful and united.

questions.question_text: During which festival do we wear new clothes and burst crackers?
questions.explanation_correct: During Diwali, we wear new clothes and burst crackers. But we should be careful and not burst too many crackers to keep the air clean.
questions.explanation_incorrect: During Holi we play with colours, Pongal is for cooking sweet rice, and Baisakhi is for harvest dancing. We burst crackers during Diwali.

questions.question_text: Christmas is celebrated on 25 December every year.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Christmas is celebrated on 25 December every year. It is the birthday of Jesus Christ.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. Christmas is indeed celebrated on 25 December every year across the world.

questions.question_text: John's family is decorating a Christmas tree and placing gifts under it. Which festival are they getting ready for?
questions.explanation_correct: John's family is getting ready for Christmas. Decorating a Christmas tree and placing gifts under it are part of Christmas celebrations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diwali has diyas, Eid has sewaiyan, and Holi has colours. Decorating a Christmas tree and placing gifts is part of Christmas.

questions.question_text: Which of these is a national day, not a religious festival?
questions.explanation_correct: Republic Day is a national day, not a religious festival. All Indians celebrate it together on 26 January.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diwali, Eid, and Christmas are religious festivals celebrated by different communities. Republic Day is a national day for all Indians.

questions.question_text: What do families do together during festivals?

options.text: Eat together, sing, and have fun

questions.explanation_correct: During festivals, families eat together, sing, dance, and have fun. Festivals are a time for togetherness and joy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Festivals are not about fighting or staying away. Families come together, eat, sing, dance, and have a wonderful time during festivals.

questions.question_text: What special dance is done during Baisakhi in Punjab?
questions.explanation_correct: Bhangra is a lively dance performed during Baisakhi in Punjab. People dance and sing to celebrate the harvest.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bharatanatyam is from Tamil Nadu, Kathak is from North India, and Odissi is from Odisha. Bhangra is the dance performed during Baisakhi in Punjab.

questions.question_text: Which of these festivals celebrates a good harvest of crops?
questions.explanation_correct: Pongal is a harvest festival. Farmers celebrate Pongal to thank the sun and rain for a good harvest of crops.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diwali is the festival of lights, Christmas is the birthday of Jesus, and Raksha Bandhan is for brothers and sisters. Pongal celebrates a good harvest.

questions.question_text: We make rangoli during Holi.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. We make rangoli during Diwali, not Holi. During Holi, we play with colours and water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is false. Rangoli is made during Diwali. During Holi, people play with gulal (coloured powder) and water.

questions.question_text: Leena's neighbour celebrates Eid. Leena's family celebrates Diwali. They share sweets with each other. What does this show?
questions.explanation_correct: This shows that they respect each other's festivals. Sharing sweets during different festivals shows love, respect, and unity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sharing sweets between neighbours who celebrate different festivals shows respect and love. Both festivals are equally good and beautiful.

questions.question_text: Who gives gifts to children during Christmas?
questions.explanation_correct: Santa Claus gives gifts to children during Christmas. Children believe Santa brings gifts in a big red bag.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Teachers teach us, postmen deliver letters, and doctors treat sick people. During Christmas, Santa Claus is the one who gives gifts to children.

questions.question_text: A farmer is very happy because his rice crop is ready. He thanks the sun god and cooks sweet rice. Which festival is this?
questions.explanation_correct: This is Pongal. During Pongal, farmers thank the sun god for a good harvest and cook sweet rice called Pongal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Holi is for colours, Diwali is for lights, and Eid is after Ramadan. Thanking the sun god and cooking sweet rice is part of Pongal.

questions.question_text: During festivals, we should ___.
questions.explanation_correct: During festivals, we should share happiness with everyone. Festivals are a time to spread love, joy, and kindness.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Being rude, angry, or silent is not what festivals are about. We should share happiness, love, and kindness with everyone during festivals.

questions.question_text: India has only one festival.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. India has many, many festivals! Diwali, Holi, Eid, Christmas, Pongal, Baisakhi, Onam, and many more.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is false. India is a land of many festivals. People of different religions and regions celebrate many different festivals.

questions.question_text: Match the festival with what we do: Diwali = Light diyas, Holi = ?
questions.explanation_correct: During Holi, we play with colours. Just as Diwali is known for lighting diyas, Holi is known for playing with colours.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Decorating a tree is Christmas, tying a rakhi is Raksha Bandhan. During Holi, we play with colours (gulal) and water.

questions.question_text: Which festival is NOT a harvest festival?
questions.explanation_correct: Diwali is not a harvest festival. It is the festival of lights. Pongal, Baisakhi, and Onam are all harvest festivals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pongal, Baisakhi, and Onam are all harvest festivals from different parts of India. Diwali is the festival of lights, not a harvest festival.

questions.question_text: On Independence Day, children sing patriotic songs at school. Why?

options.text: To show love for our country

questions.explanation_correct: Children sing patriotic songs on Independence Day to show love for our country. It is a way to honour India and our freedom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While children may enjoy singing, the main reason for singing patriotic songs on Independence Day is to show love and respect for our country.

questions.question_text: During festivals, many people burst loud crackers late at night. Is this a good habit?

options.text: No, it disturbs others and pollutes the air

questions.explanation_correct: Bursting loud crackers late at night is not a good habit. It disturbs people who are sleeping and pollutes the air. We can celebrate with diyas and sweets instead.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Loud crackers late at night disturb neighbours, scare animals, and cause air pollution. It is better to celebrate with diyas, sweets, and spending time with family.

questions.question_text: Eid is celebrated after the holy month of ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Eid is celebrated after the holy month of Ramadan. During Ramadan, people fast from sunrise to sunset, and then celebrate Eid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: January, December, and March are English calendar months. Eid comes after Ramadan, which is a holy month of fasting.

questions.question_text: On Independence Day, we hoist the national flag and sing the national anthem.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. On Independence Day (15 August), we hoist the national flag and sing our national anthem, Jana Gana Mana.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. Hoisting the flag and singing the national anthem are important parts of Independence Day celebrations.

questions.question_text: Why is India called a 'land of festivals'?

options.text: Because we have only two festivals
Because people of many religions celebrate many festivals here

questions.explanation_correct: India is called a land of festivals because people of many religions and cultures celebrate many different festivals throughout the year.
questions.explanation_incorrect: India has people of many religions â€” Hindu, Muslim, Christian, Sikh, and more. Each community has its own festivals, making India a land of festivals.

questions.question_text: Which pair is correct?
questions.explanation_correct: Christmas - Christmas tree is the correct pair. During Christmas, people decorate a Christmas tree.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diwali goes with diyas (not colours), Holi goes with colours (not diyas), and Eid goes with sewaiyan (not rangoli). Christmas - Christmas tree is correct.

questions.question_text: Your friend celebrates a different festival than you. What should you do?

options.text: Respect the festival and wish your friend
Tell your friend their festival is wrong

questions.explanation_correct: We should respect our friend's festival and wish them. All festivals are beautiful and we should celebrate together.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Making fun of or disrespecting someone's festival is wrong. We should always respect different festivals and wish our friends happiness.

questions.question_text: During which festival do people fast and then celebrate by eating together?
questions.explanation_correct: During Eid, people celebrate after fasting during the month of Ramadan. They eat delicious food like sewaiyan together.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Holi is for colours, Pongal for harvest, and Baisakhi for harvest in Punjab. Eid is the festival where people celebrate after fasting during Ramadan.

questions.question_text: Only one type of people celebrate festivals in India.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. People of many religions and cultures celebrate festivals in India. Hindus, Muslims, Christians, Sikhs, and many more celebrate different festivals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is false. India has people of many religions and cultures. Each community celebrates its own festivals, and often everyone joins in.

questions.question_text: What is the BEST thing about festivals?

options.text: Being together with family and sharing happiness

questions.explanation_correct: The best thing about festivals is being together with family and sharing happiness. Festivals are about love, togetherness, and joy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While holidays and food are nice, the most important thing about festivals is being together with family, sharing love, and spreading happiness.
